p: Malaria reintroduction in the territories that had been freed from it is one of the critical issues of malaria control in the 21st century [ 3]. In the pre-elimination era, malaria was endemic in most of the European countries, including a considerable part of Russia. In Europe, all of the species of malaria ever present (that is P. malariae, P. falciparum, and P. vivax) had been eliminated in the mid-20th century, and vivax malaria was the last one to disappear. Since then, short-living episodes of the autochthonous transmission of P. vivax have been documented in a number of European countries, and, among them, Russia was the most affected.
